Text.Value: A philosopher... Who could've thought. Name's Zorru.
At least you made it. How are you holding up?
He was weak. He broke, and made a broken man's decision. And we all suffered for it.
We were in a bad place and walked into an ambush. Our only options were fight or surrender.
Oh, he deserves it. Trust me.
I wanted to ask you about Zevlor.
For taking those matters of life and death on himself. That burden weighed on his conscience instead of yours.
So, you survived. That's more than many of my kin can say.
I am sorry. It sounds like Zevlor was just overwhelmed.
He made a mistake. Everyone does, now and then.
They may have a point. The city can't handle all these refugees.
What did Zevlor do that makes you say that?
I'm not in the mood. Leave me alone.
No need for you to apologise. The news of his death is some consolation, at least. Though not much.
He was afraid for your lives and made a frightened man's decision.
His mistake cost lives - tieflings died who should be alive today. I can't forgive that.
It's easy to second-guess a leader afterwards. At the time, he hoped to avoid a massacre.
Zevlor froze. I shook him, demanded orders, answers, but he just stared at me.
Leave.
Spare me your sanctimony. He died a failure, with the blood of the tieflings he should have protected on his hands.
I haven't seen him since the massacre on the road. Which is lucky for him.
For all the good that does either of us. And now you say Zevlor's dead. Well, I say good riddance.
I heard about you. You're the one that helped us with the goblins.
You know most of us didn't make it, right? Zevlor failed us.
Really? Then we have nothing to say to each other.
None is possible. At least now he's paid for his betrayal.
We owe Zevlor...? For what?
It's all right, I'm not mad about it anymore. He tried his best to lead us in a terrible situation. I see that now.
I have nothing more to say to you. Leave me to mourn our dead.
A leader makes the hard decisions so you don't have to. You owe Zevlor a debt.
That loser? Don't bother. I don't even want to think about him after what he did.
I spoke to him before his death. He admitted his failure, but had no convincing explanation for his surrender.
Oh. Hello again.
Zevlor is dead - murdered. His severed head was sent to my camp.
No wonder you're furious. I'm furious just hearing about it.
Those are... just words. I'm talking about lives. Go away and leave me to my grief.
Ha! A jest is welcome in times like these. I'm Zorru.
That seems harsh.
What do you make of those protestors?
He's dead? Then there's some justice in the world, after all.
I wanted to ask you about Zevlor.
I think they're grabbing the wrong end of the rothé.
It's not too much to ask a leader to lead. When the crisis came, he failed us.
When the attackers closed in, he woke up - and told our fighters to stand down.
Reactions like that are inevitable. People are afraid.
He wouldn't fight, so we did what he said and surrendered. They rounded us up and marched us to Moonrise.
I spoke with him before his death. He felt he had no choice but to act as he did.
It's mainly anger that keeps me going. Zevlor was supposed to lead us, but he froze when we needed him most.
No choice? We could have fought, and would have if he'd led the way. We might have lost, but it was a chance. Surrendering was certain death.
He led you, fought for you, and ultimately died for you.
Most of us never marched out again.

Synopsis: Zorru is furious after being left behind by Zevlor who is supposed to lead them
